attributes.alt: Book cover for Baby Goes to Market by Atinuke, illustrated by Angela Brooksbank. The cover art shows a mother carrying her young child on her back and smiling.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking:
“What is one food people sell at the  market?”
Read for enjoyment, pausing to practice operations.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Use numerals 0—5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Understand that adding or taking away one from a small group of objects changes the total quantity by one.
Count forward or backward from a given number up to 5 to solve a problem.
Blend two or more syllables to create words.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Understand and use a growing number of theme words.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Help children count the Connecting Cube “fruits” they have in their market stall as a “farmer” gives them more to sell.
Guide children to point to the Magnetic Numeral that matches the number of “fruits” they have.
What foods do we like?  Where do they come from?
What foods are in that book?
Can you pretend to be a farmer? What fruit will you gather to sell at the market?
How many pieces of fruit did you count?
What fruit can you draw? What color is it?
What materials can you use to make a piece of fruit?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of
? How many syllables are in the word
How can you use blocks to build a basket to hold fruit?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Baby Goes to Market by Atinuke, illustrated by Angela Brooksbank. The cover art shows a mother carrying her young child on her back and smiling.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
talk about the feelings of others
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to identify and discuss characters’ emotions.
Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Count forward or backward from a given number up to 5 to solve a problem.
Use pre-reading skills in self-selected books.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Help children identify, describe, and sort facial expressions.
Guide children to count the Activity Cards in each category
and show how many there are.
What foods do we like? Where do they come from?
Can you show me someone eating in this book?
How can you use your whole body to act surprised?
Can you make a market basket with five healthy foods in it?
What could you write about how you feel today?
Can you make a person who is eating healthy food?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of
Can you build a market? What foods are people selling?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Baby Goes to Market by Atinuke, illustrated by Angela Brooksbank. The cover art shows a mother carrying her young child on her back and smiling.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share an operations strategy, play an addition game, and introduce vocabulary
“What is one way Baby feels at the market?”
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review operations.
Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Understand that adding or taking away one from a small group of objects changes the total quantity by one.
Count forward or backward from a given number up to 5 to solve a problem.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Understand and use a growing number of theme words.
Use Number Cards to create a number line.
Guide children to use the number line to solve verbal word problems about adding and taking away foods from a shopping basket.
What foods do we like? Where do they come from?
How are the foods in that book similar to the foods you eat?
Pretend you are visiting a new place. How will you find new foods there?
How can you take away two fruits from that group? How many are left?
Can you write about how you find food at a market?
Can you create a food that you want to buy at the market?
? How can you write the word
Baby sees many different fruits at the market. How can you use blocks to show the different fruit Baby saw?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas page for Let's Make Fruit Salad! The chart shows ingredients including 3 sliced bananas, 2 cups of sliced apples, 1 cup of sliced strawberries, and 2 cut-up mangoes. Next are directions for making fruit salad: 1. Wash the fruit. 2. Peel the bananas and ask an adult to help cut all the fruit. 3. Use measuring cups to measure the apples and strawberries and put them in the bowl. 4. Add the mangoes to the bowl. 5. Mix all of the fruit together. Finally, serve the fruit salad. Enjoy!
Book cover for Baby Goes to Market by Atinuke, illustrated by Angela Brooksbank. The cover art shows a mother carrying her young child on her back and smiling.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to reflect on learning and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to this week’s essential question:
What foods do we like? Where do they come from?
Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Understand that adding or taking away one from a small group of objects changes the total quantity by one.
Count forward or backward from a given number up to 5 to solve a problem.
Measure, describe, and compare capacity or how much can be placed inside an object using like units and words like “empty” and “full.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Understand and use a growing number of theme words.
Have children make a “fruit salad” using Connecting Cubes.
Guide children to identify numerals and contribute the correct amount of “ingredients” to the “salad.”
What foods do we like?  Where do they come from?
What food in this book do you think would be the tastiest?
Let’s pretend we are chefs with two different ideas for a dish. Let’s compare the dishes and choose one to make.
Which bunch of fruits is the biggest? How can you tell?
What healthy food do you think is the tastiest? Write about it!
Can you make a collage that shows the ingredients of your favorite dish?
Think of some some other shapes you can build with the blocks. Can you compare the size of the shapes you build?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Baby Goes to Market by Atinuke, illustrated by Angela Brooksbank. The cover art shows a mother carrying her young child on her back and smiling.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to connect to social studies, play a measurement game, and introduce vocabulary
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
“If you went to the market, what healthy food would you buy?”
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Count forward or backward from a given number up to 5 to solve a problem.
Measure, describe, and compare capacity or how much can be placed inside an object using like units and words like “empty” and “full.
Use pretend money during play, earning money for work, and using money to buy goods and services.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
“Write a story about someone who buys healthy foods at a market.”
Save children’s writing to display next week.
What foods do we like?  Where do they come from?
What kind of book do you want to read next?
Imagine you are visiting a market! Pretend to buy some new foods you have never tasted before.
How can you create a new fruit that grows in bunches of three?
Can you write a story about discovering a new fruit?
Imagine what your new fruit looks like. What will you use to create it?
Create a name for your new fruit. What letter(s) does it begin with?
Pretend you are selling your new fruit. Can you work together to build a market stand to sell it?
